title: Machine Learning Enhanced Tomographic Imaging of Chemical Short-range Order in Fe-based Solid Solutions
content: Chemical short-range order (CSRO) refers to atoms of specific elements self-organizing within a disordered crystalline matrix to form particular atomic neighborhoods, which can change the mechanical and functional properties of materials. CSRO is typically characterized indirectly, using volume-averaged (e.g. X-ray/neutron scattering) or through projection (i.e. two-dimensional) microscopy techniques that fail to capture the complex, three-dimensional (3D) atomistic architectures. Quantitative assessment of CSRO and concrete structure-property relationships have remained so far unachievable. Fe-Al alloys, known for their lightweight nature and exceptional strength, corrosion resistance, and wear resistance, present ideal candidates for theoretical studies on ordering transformations. Undeformed Fe-Al alloys, particularly those with compositions near the boundary of the disorder-order transition, when annealed at e.g., 523 K and subsequently quenched, often exhibit an anomalous increase in electrical resistivity. This peculiar behavior is attributed to the K-state, initially identified in 1951 and commonly associated with D03-CSRO (Fe3Al-like), marking the onset of long-range ordering reactions. Similar K-state behavior was observed in other Fe-X (X=Si, Ga, Cr) alloys. However, the underlying mechanisms of the K-state remain unclear, and the quantitative characterization of CSRO poses a significant challenge.
